column2: FROM VIRGINIA, MARYLAND AND DELAWARE.
column3: FROM VIRGINIA, MARYLAND AND DELAWARE.

column2: ARCHER BARLOW, ALIAS EMIT ROBINS.
column3: ARCHER BARLOW, ALIAS EMIT ROBINS.

column2: This passenger arrived from Norfolk, Va. in 1853.
column3: This passenger arrived from norfolk virginia in eighteen fifty three.

column2: For the last four years previous to escaping, he had been under the yoke of Dr. George Wilson.
column3: For the last four years previous to escaping, he had been under the yoke of dr George Wilson.

column2: Archer declared that he had been "very badly treated" by the Doctor, which he urged as his reason for leaving.
column3: Archer declared that he had been "very badly treated" by the Doctor, which he urged as his reason for leaving.

column2: True, the doctor had been good enough to allow him to hire his time, for which he required Archer to pay the moderate sum of $120 per annum.
column3: True, the doctor had been good enough to allow him to hire his time, for which he required Archer to pay the moderate sum of one hundred twenty dollars per annum.

column2: As Archer had been "sickly" most of the time, during the last year, he complained that there was "no reduction" in his hire on this account.
column3: As Archer had been "sickly" most of the time, during the last year, he complained that there was "no reduction" in his hire on this account.

column2: Upon reflection, therefore, Archer thought, if he had justice done him, he would be in possession of this "one hundred and twenty" himself, and all his other rights, instead of having to toil for another without pay; so he looked seriously into the matter of master and slave, and pretty soon resolved, that if others chose to make no effort to get away, for himself he would never be contented, until he was free.
column3: Upon reflection, therefore, Archer thought, if he had justice done him, he would be in possession of this "one hundred and twenty" himself, and all his other rights, instead of having to toil for another without pay; so he looked seriously into the matter of master and slave, and pretty soon resolved, that if others chose to make no effort to get away, for himself he would never be contented, until he was free.

column2: When a slave reached this decision, he was in a very hopeful state.
column3: When a slave reached this decision, he was in a very hopeful state.

column2: He was near the Underground Rail Road, and was sure to find it, sooner or later.
column3: He was near the Underground Rail Road, and was sure to find it, sooner or later.

column2: At this thoughtful period, Archer was thirty-one years of age, a man of medium size, and belonged to the two leading branches of southern humanity, _i.e._, he _was_ half white and half colored--a dark mulatto.
column3: At this thoughtful period, Archer was thirty one years of age, a man of medium size, and belonged to the two leading branches of southern humanity, underscore i e underscore, he underscore was underscore half white and half colored-a dark mulatto.

column2: His arrival in Philadelphia, per one of the Richmond steamers, was greeted with joy by the Vigilance Committee, who extended to him the usual aid and care, and forwarded him on to freedom.
column3: His arrival in Philadelphia, per one of the Richmond steamers, was greeted with joy by the Vigilance Committee, who extended to him the usual aid and care, and forwarded him on to freedom.

column2: For a number of years, he has been a citizen of Boston.
column3: For a number of years, he has been a citizen of Boston.

column2: SAMUEL BUSH, ALIAS WILLIAM OBLEBEE.
column3: SAMUEL BUSH, ALIAS WILLIAM o b l e b e e.

column2: This "piece of property" fled in the fall of 1853.
column3: This "piece of property" fled in the fall of eighteen fifty three.

column2: As a specimen of this article of commerce, he evinced considerable intelligence.
column3: As a specimen of this article of commerce, he evinced considerable intelligence.

column2: He was a man of dark color, although not totally free from the admixture of the "superior" southern blood in his veins; in stature, he was only ordinary.
column3: He was a man of dark color, although not totally free from the admixture of the "superior" southern blood in his veins; in stature, he was only ordinary.

column2: For leaving, he gave the following reasons: "I found that I was working for my master, for his advantage, and when I was sick, I had to pay just as much as if I were well--$7 a month.
column3: For leaving, he gave the following reasons: "I found that I was working for my master, for his advantage, and when I was sick, I had to pay just as much as if I were well-seven dollars a month.

column2: But my master was cross, and said that he intended to sell me--to do better by me another year.
column3: But my master was cross, and said that he intended to sell me-to do better by me another year.

column2: Times grew worse and worse, constantly.
column3: Times grew worse and worse, constantly.

column2: I thought, as I had heard, that if I could raise thirty dollars I could come away." He at once saw the value of money.
column3: I thought, as I had heard, that if I could raise thirty dollars I could come away." He at once saw the value of money.

column2: To his mind it meant liberty from that moment. Thenceforth he decided to treasure up every dollar he could get hold of until he could accumulate at least enough to get out of "Old Virginia." He was a married man, and thought he had a wife and one child, but on reflection, he found out that they did not actually belong to him, but to a carpenter, by the name of Bailey.
column3: To his mind it meant liberty from that moment. Thenceforth he decided to treasure up every dollar he could get hold of until he could accumulate at least enough to get out of "Old Virginia." He was a married man, and thought he had a wife and one child, but on reflection, he found out that they did not actually belong to him, but to a carpenter, by the name of Bailey.

column2: The man whom Samuel was compelled to call master was named Hoyle.
column3: The man whom Samuel was compelled to call master was named Hoyle.

column2: The Committee's interview with Samuel was quite satisfactory, and they cheerfully accorded to him brotherly kindness and material aid at the same time.
column3: The Committee's interview with Samuel was quite satisfactory, and they cheerfully accorded to him brotherly kindness and material aid at the same time.

column2: JOHN SPENCER AND HIS SON WILLIAM, AND JAMES ALBERT.
column3: john SPENCER AND HIS SON WILLIAM, AND james ALBERT.

column2: These individuals escaped from the eastern shore of Maryland, in the Spring of 1853, but were led to conclude that they could enjoy the freedom they had aimed to find, in New Jersey.
column3: These individuals escaped from the eastern shore of Maryland, in the Spring of eighteen fifty three, but were led to conclude that they could enjoy the freedom they had aimed to find, in New Jersey.

column2: They procured employment in the neighborhood of Haddonfield, some six or eight miles from Camden, New Jersey, and were succeeding, as they thought, very well.
column3: They procured employment in the neighborhood of Haddonfield, some six or eight miles from camden new jersey, and were succeeding, as they thought, very well.

column2: Things went on favorably for about three months, when to their alarm "slave-hunters were discovered in the neighborhood," and sufficient evidence was obtained to make it quite plain that, John, William and James were the identical persons, for whom the hunters were in "hot pursuit." When brought to the Committee, they were pretty thoroughly alarmed and felt very anxious to be safely off to Canada.
column3: Things went on favorably for about three months, when to their alarm "slave hunters were discovered in the neighborhood," and sufficient evidence was obtained to make it quite plain that, john, William and james were the identical persons, for whom the hunters were in "hot pursuit." When brought to the Committee, they were pretty thoroughly alarmed and felt very anxious to be safely off to Canada.

column2: While the Committee always rendered in such cases immediate protection and aid, they nevertheless, felt, in view of the imminent dangers existing under the fugitive slave law, that persons disposed to thus stop by the way, should be very plainly given to understand, that if they were captured they would have themselves the most to blame.
column3: While the Committee always rendered in such cases immediate protection and aid, they nevertheless, felt, in view of the imminent dangers existing under the fugitive slave law, that persons disposed to thus stop by the way, should be very plainly given to understand, that if they were captured they would have themselves the most to blame.

column2: But the dread of Slavery was strong in the minds of these fugitives, and they very fully realized their folly in stopping in New Jersey.
column3: But the dread of Slavery was strong in the minds of these fugitives, and they very fully realized their folly in stopping in New Jersey.

column2: The Committee procured their tickets, helped them to disguise themselves as much as possible, and admonished them not to stop short of Canada.
column3: The Committee procured their tickets, helped them to disguise themselves as much as possible, and admonished them not to stop short of Canada.

column2: HETTY SCOTT ALIAS MARGARET DUNCANS AND DAUGHTER PRISCILLA.
column3: HETTY SCOTT ALIAS MARGARET DUNCANS AND DAUGHTER PRISCILLA.

column2: This mother and daughter had been the "chattels personal" of Daniel Coolby of Harvard, Md.
column3: This mother and daughter had been the "chattels personal" of Daniel Coolby of Harvard, m d.

column2: Their lot had been that of ordinary slaves in the country, on farms, &c.
column3: Their lot had been that of ordinary slaves in the country, on farms, and c.

column2: The motive which prompted them to escape was the fact that their master had "threatened to sell" them.
column3: The motive which prompted them to escape was the fact that their master had "threatened to sell" them.

column2: He had a right to do so; but Hetty was a little squeamish on this point and took great umbrage at her "kind master." In this "disobedient" state of mind, she determined, if hard struggling would enable her, to defeat the threats of Mr. Daniel Coolby, that he should not much longer have the satisfaction of enjoying the fruit of the toil of herself and offspring. She at once began to prepare for her journey.
column3: He had a right to do so; but Hetty was a little squeamish on this point and took great umbrage at her "kind master." In this "disobedient" state of mind, she determined, if hard struggling would enable her, to defeat the threats of mr Daniel Coolby, that he should not much longer have the satisfaction of enjoying the fruit of the toil of herself and offspring. She at once began to prepare for her journey.

column2: She had three children of her own to bring, besides she was intimately acquainted with a young man and a young woman, both slaves, to whom she felt that it would be safe to confide her plans with a view of inviting them to accompany her.
column3: She had three children of her own to bring, besides she was intimately acquainted with a young man and a young woman, both slaves, to whom she felt that it would be safe to confide her plans with a view of inviting them to accompany her.

column2: The young couple were ready converts to the eloquent speech delivered to them by Hetty on Freedom, and were quite willing to accept her as their leader in the emergency.
column3: The young couple were ready converts to the eloquent speech delivered to them by Hetty on Freedom, and were quite willing to accept her as their leader in the emergency.

column2: Up to the hour of setting out on their lonely and fatiguing journey, arrangements were being carefully completed, so that there should be no delay of any kind. At the appointed hour they were all moving northward in good order.
column3: Up to the hour of setting out on their lonely and fatiguing journey, arrangements were being carefully completed, so that there should be no delay of any kind. At the appointed hour they were all moving northward in good order.

column2: Arriving at Quakertown, Pa., they found friends of the slave, who welcomed them to their homes and sympathy, gladdening the hearts of all concerned.
column3: Arriving at Quakertown, Pa., they found friends of the slave, who welcomed them to their homes and sympathy, gladdening the hearts of all concerned.

column2: For prudential reasons it was deemed desirable to separate the party, to send some one way and some another.
column3: For prudential reasons it was deemed desirable to separate the party, to send some one way and some another.

column2: Thus safely, through the kind offices and aid of the friends at Quakertown, they were duly forwarded on to the Committee in Philadelphia.
column3: Thus safely, through the kind offices and aid of the friends at Quakertown, they were duly forwarded on to the Committee in Philadelphia.

column2: Here similar acts of charity were extended to them, and they were directed on to Canada.
column3: Here similar acts of charity were extended to them, and they were directed on to Canada.

column2: ROBERT FISHER.
column3: ROBERT FISHER.

column2: THIS PASSENGER AVAILS HIMSELF OF HOLIDAY WEEK, BETWEEN CHRISTMAS AND NEW YEAR'S, TO MAKE HIS NORTHERN TRIP.
column3: THIS PASSENGER AVAILS HIMSELF OF HOLIDAY WEEK, BETWEEN CHRISTMAS AND NEW YEAR'S, TO MAKE HIS NORTHERN TRIP.

column2: Robert was about thirty years of age, dark color, quite tall, and in talking with him a little while, it was soon discovered that Slavery had not crushed all the brains out of his head by a good deal.
column3: Robert was about thirty years of age, dark color, quite tall, and in talking with him a little while, it was soon discovered that Slavery had not crushed all the brains out of his head by a good deal.

column2: Nor was he so much attached to his "kind-hearted master," John Edward Jackson, of Anne Arundel, Md., or his old fiddle, that he was contented and happy while in bondage.
column3: Nor was he so much attached to his "kind hearted master," john Edward Jackson, of Anne Arundel, m d., or his old fiddle, that he was contented and happy while in bondage.

column2: Far from it.
column3: Far from it.

column2: The fact was, that he hated Slavery so decidedly and had such a clear common sense-like view of the evils and misery of the system, that he declared he had as a matter of principle refrained from marrying, in order that he might have no reason to grieve over having added to the woes of slaves.
column3: The fact was, that he hated Slavery so decidedly and had such a clear common sense like view of the evils and misery of the system, that he declared he had as a matter of principle refrained from marrying, in order that he might have no reason to grieve over having added to the woes of slaves.

column2: Nor did he wish to be encumbered, if the opportunity offered to escape.
column3: Nor did he wish to be encumbered, if the opportunity offered to escape.

column2: According to law he was entitled to his freedom at the age of twenty-five.
column3: According to law he was entitled to his freedom at the age of twenty five.

column2: But what right had a negro, which white slave-holders were "bound to respect?" Many who had been willed free, were held just as firmly in Slavery, as if no will had ever been made.
column3: But what right had a negro, which white slave holders were "bound to respect?" Many who had been willed free, were held just as firmly in Slavery, as if no will had ever been made.

column2: Robert had too much sense to suppose that he could gain anything by seeking legal redress.
column3: Robert had too much sense to suppose that he could gain anything by seeking legal redress.

column2: This method, therefore, was considered out of the question.
column3: This method, therefore, was considered out of the question.

column2: But in the meantime he was growing very naturally in favor of the Underground Rail Road.
column3: But in the meantime he was growing very naturally in favor of the Underground Rail Road.

column2: From his experience Robert did not hesitate to say that his master was "mean," "a very hard man," who would work his servants early and late, without allowing them food and clothing sufficient to shield them from the cold and hunger.
column3: From his experience Robert did not hesitate to say that his master was "mean," "a very hard man," who would work his servants early and late, without allowing them food and clothing sufficient to shield them from the cold and hunger.

column2: Robert certainly had unmistakable marks about him, of having been used roughly.
column3: Robert certainly had unmistakable marks about him, of having been used roughly.

column2: He thought very well of Nathan Harris, a fellow-servant belonging to the same owner, and he made up his mind, if Nathan would join him, neither the length of the journey, the loneliness of night travel, the coldness of the weather, the fear of the slave-hunter, nor the scantiness of their means should deter him from making his way to freedom.
column3: He thought very well of Nathan Harris, a fellow servant belonging to the same owner, and he made up his mind, if Nathan would join him, neither the length of the journey, the loneliness of night travel, the coldness of the weather, the fear of the slave hunter, nor the scantiness of their means should deter him from making his way to freedom.

column2: Nathan listened to the proposal, and was suddenly converted to freedom, and the two united during Christmas week, 1854, and set out on the Underground Rail Road.
column3: Nathan listened to the proposal, and was suddenly converted to freedom, and the two united during Christmas week, eighteen fifty four, and set out on the Underground Rail Road.

column2: It is needless to say that they had trying difficulties to encounter.
column3: It is needless to say that they had trying difficulties to encounter.

column2: These they expected, but all were overcome, and they reached the Vigilance Committee, in Philadelphia safely, and were cordially welcomed.
column3: These they expected, but all were overcome, and they reached the Vigilance Committee, in Philadelphia safely, and were cordially welcomed.

column2: During the interview, a full interchange of thought resulted, the fugitives were well cared for, and in due time both were forwarded on, free of cost.
column3: During the interview, a full interchange of thought resulted, the fugitives were well cared for, and in due time both were forwarded on, free of cost.

column2: HANSEL WAPLES.
column3: HANSEL WAPLES.

column2: This traveler arrived from Millsboro, Indian River, Delaware, where he was owned by Wm. E. Burton.
column3: This traveler arrived from Millsboro, Indian River, Delaware, where he was owned by w m. e Burton.

column2: While Hansel did not really own himself, he had the reputation of having a wife and six children.
column3: While Hansel did not really own himself, he had the reputation of having a wife and six children.

column2: In June, some six months prior to her husband's arrival, Hansel's wife had been allowed by her mistress to go out on a begging expedition, to raise money to buy herself; but contrary to the expectation of her mistress she never returned.
column3: In June, some six months prior to her husband's arrival, Hansel's wife had been allowed by her mistress to go out on a begging expedition, to raise money to buy herself; but contrary to the expectation of her mistress she never returned.

column2: Doubtless the mistress looked upon this course as a piece of the most highhanded stealing.
column3: Doubtless the mistress looked upon this course as a piece of the most highhanded stealing.

column2: Hansel did not speak of his owner as being a hard man, but on the contrary he thought that he was about as "good" as the best that he was acquainted with.
column3: Hansel did not speak of his owner as being a hard man, but on the contrary he thought that he was about as "good" as the best that he was acquainted with.

column2: While this was true, however, Hansel had quite good ground for believing that his master was about to sell him.
column3: While this was true, however, Hansel had quite good ground for believing that his master was about to sell him.

column2: Dreading this fate he made up his mind to go in pursuit of his wife to a Free state.
column3: Dreading this fate he made up his mind to go in pursuit of his wife to a Free state.

column2: Exactly where to look or how to find her he could not tell.
column3: Exactly where to look or how to find her he could not tell.

column2: The Committee advised him to "search in Canada." And in order to enable him to get on quickly and safely, the Committee aided him with money, &c., in 1853.
column3: The Committee advised him to "search in Canada." And in order to enable him to get on quickly and safely, the Committee aided him with money, and c., in eighteen fifty three.

column2: ROSE ANNA TONNELL ALIAS MARIA HYDE.

column2: She fled from Isaac Tonnell of Georgetown, Delaware, in Christmas week, 1853.
column3: She fled from Isaac Tonnell of Georgetown, Delaware, in Christmas week, eighteen fifty three.

column2: A young woman with a little boy of seven years of age accompanied Rose Anna.
column3: A young woman with a little boy of seven years of age accompanied Rose Anna.

column3: Further than the simple fact of their having thus safely arrived, except the expense incurred by the Committee, no other particulars appear on the records.

column2: MARY ENNIS ALIAS LICIA HEMMIN.
column3: MARY ENNIS ALIAS LICIA h e m m i n.

column2: Mary arrived with her two children in the early Spring of 1854.
column3: Mary arrived with her two children in the early Spring of eighteen fifty four.

column2: The mother was a woman of about thirty-three years of age, quite tall, with a countenance and general appearance well fitted to awaken sympathy at first sight.
column3: The mother was a woman of about thirty three years of age, quite tall, with a countenance and general appearance well fitted to awaken sympathy at first sight.

column2: Her oldest child was a little girl seven years of age, named Lydia; the other was named Louisa Caroline, three years of age, both promising in appearance.
column3: Her oldest child was a little girl seven years of age, named Lydia; the other was named Louisa Caroline, three years of age, both promising in appearance.

column2: They were the so called property of John Ennis, of Georgetown, Delaware.
column3: They were the so called property of john Ennis, of Georgetown, Delaware.

column2: For their flight they chose the dead of Winter.
column3: For their flight they chose the dead of Winter.

column2: After leaving they made their way to West Chester, and there found friends and security for several weeks, up to the time they reached Philadelphia.
column3: After leaving they made their way to West Chester, and there found friends and security for several weeks, up to the time they reached Philadelphia.

column2: Probably the friends with whom they stopped thought the weather too inclement for a woman with children dependent on her support to travel.
column3: Probably the friends with whom they stopped thought the weather too inclement for a woman with children dependent on her support to travel.

column2: Long before this mother escaped, thoughts of liberty filled her heart.
column3: Long before this mother escaped, thoughts of liberty filled her heart.

column2: She was ever watching for an opportunity, that would encourage her to hope for safety, when once the attempt should be made.
column3: She was ever watching for an opportunity, that would encourage her to hope for safety, when once the attempt should be made.

column2: Until, however, she was convinced that her two children were to be sold, she could not quite muster courage to set out on the journey.
column3: Until, however, she was convinced that her two children were to be sold, she could not quite muster courage to set out on the journey.

column2: This threat to sell proved in multitudes of instances, "the last straw on the camel's back." When nothing else would start them this would.
column3: This threat to sell proved in multitudes of instances, "the last straw on the camel's back." When nothing else would start them this would.

column2: Mary and her children were the only slaves owned by this Ennis, consequently her duties were that of "Jack of all trades;" sometimes in the field and sometimes in the barn, as well as in the kitchen, by which, it is needless to say, that her life was rendered servile to the last degree.
column3: Mary and her children were the only slaves owned by this Ennis, consequently her duties were that of "Jack of all trades;" sometimes in the field and sometimes in the barn, as well as in the kitchen, by which, it is needless to say, that her life was rendered servile to the last degree.

column2: To bind up the broken heart of such a poor slave mother, and to aid such tender plants as were these little girls, from such a wretched state of barbarism as existed in poor little Delaware, was doubly gratifying to the Committee.
column3: To bind up the broken heart of such a poor slave mother, and to aid such tender plants as were these little girls, from such a wretched state of barbarism as existed in poor little Delaware, was doubly gratifying to the Committee.
